item.title: Coronavirus: UK quarantine plans and Â£1,000 penalties set out
item.description: The 14-day isolation for arrivals is needed to protect "hard-won progress", the home secretary says.

item.title: Coronavirus: 24-hour test results 'by end of June'
item.description: The PM's promise comes as a union calls for more transparency over the accuracy of coronavirus tests.

item.title: Coronavirus: Schools to reopen in Wales on 29 June
item.description: Parents who choose not to send their children to school when they reopen will not be fined.

item.title: PMQs: Starmer accuses PM of ignoring virus help offer
item.description: Boris Johnson said the Labour leader's attacks on government were undermining "public trust and confidence".

item.title: George Floyd death: Hundreds join London protest
item.description: It comes as UK police chiefs say they stand alongside all those "appalled and horrified" by the death.

item.title: Man charged with murdering wife and daughter in Salisbury
item.description: Nikoletta Zdun, 18, and Aneta Zdun, 40, died at a home in Salisbury on Monday.

item.title: Coronavirus contact tracer 'paid to watch Netflix'
item.description: A clinician on the NHS Test and Trace scheme tells the BBC of her frustration at not receiving work.

item.title: Disruption to schools could continue to November, MPs told
item.description: Disruption to school in England could continue into the autumn until November, MPs are told

item.title: Harlesden street party of 500 people broken up by police
item.description: Videos on social media show hundreds of people drinking and dancing into the early hours.

item.title: Coronavirus: France's virus-tracing app 'off to a good start'
item.description: France's digital minister says 600,000 people installed the app in its first hours of release.

item.title: Coronavirus: Sweden's Tegnell admits too many died
item.description: Anders Tegnell says more should have been done early on to stem coronavirus in Sweden.

item.title: Norfolk health worker reunited with daughters after nine weeks
item.description: Suzie Vaughan says she thought her "heart was going to burst" when she saw her daughters again.

item.title: Fleabag and Game of Thrones up for 'must-see moment' Bafta
item.description: Viewers have until 15 July to cast their vote for the only Bafta TV award decided on by the public.

item.title: Coronavirus: London key workers to star on cover of British Vogue
item.description: Community midwife Rachel Millar describes being on the cover of Vogue as "surreal".

item.title: George Floyd death: The man who sheltered 80 US protesters
item.description: Hundreds of people found themselves trapped by police - until Rahul Dubey flung open his doors.

item.title: Portraits of Humanity shortlist revealed
item.description: Two hundred shortlisted photos aim to show there is more that unites us than sets us apart.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Our son with Down's syndrome is thriving in lockdown'
item.description: Zachary, 4, has been hospitalised with chest infections many times, but his parents say he has never been so well.

item.title: Asian hornet: UK beekeepers on lookout for bee-eater
item.description: The bee-eating Asian hornet has already reached the Channel Islands and beekeepers fear it could soon reach the UK mainland.

item.title: OK Beeb: BBC voice assistant will learn regional accents
item.description: A male northern voice is the BBC's initial choice for its voice assistant, in the testing phase.

item.title: Coronavirus: No Botox and no fillers under lockdown
item.description: Living without fillers and Botox under lockdown is a mental health challenge for some individuals.

item.title: Charles Dickens: Black-and-white photos of author colourised
item.description: Colour has been digitally added to eight photos to show what the novelist would have looked like.

item.title: Massive queues as McDonald's reopens Scottish drive-thru restaurants
item.description: Police have directed long queues of traffic at some Scottish McDonald's drive-thrus.

item.title: George Floyd protests: Trudeau's epic pause when asked about Trump's response
item.description: Asked about race, unrest and the US response, the Canadian prime minister chose his words carefully.

item.title: How coronavirus tore through Britain's ethnic minorities
item.description: Covid-19 has affected BAME people disproportionately. Now they want to know why.

item.title: Philando Castile death: 'I lost my best friend in a police shooting'
item.description: Four years before George Floyd's death made global headlines, another man was shot dead in the same city.

item.title: PMQs: Labour leader Starmer's political distancing
item.description: There is a change in tone from the opposition leader towards Boris Johnson, but what is his plan?

item.title: Enjoying lockdown: 'Not having anything in my diary was a blessing in disguise'
item.description: For people whose diaries are usually full, the quarantine period has made them reassess their priorities.

item.title: Shielders face dilemma: Should I go outside or not?
item.description: People in England and Wales shielding with health conditions are able to leave home. Some don't want to.

item.title: Peter Crouch on jumping from planes and 'the ultimate retirement'
item.description: The retired footballer had to jump out of a plane for his new Saturday night BBC One show.

item.title: How World in Motion heralded England's leap out of the dark ages
item.description: How New Order's World in Motion topped the charts 30 years ago, symbolising a "cultural revolution".

item.title: George Floyd death: Trump's church visit shocks religious leaders
item.description: The divisive US president's visit to a church amid ongoing nationwide protests drew heavy criticism.

item.title: George Floyd protests: Misleading footage and conspiracy theories spread online
item.description: Protests after the death of George Floyd have led to a surge in misleading videos and unfounded theories.

item.title: George Floyd: Can President Trump deploy the military?
item.description: With protests continuing across the US, President Trump says he could send in troops.

item.title: Coronavirus: The London hospital hit by a 'tidal wave' of patients
item.description: Northwick Park Hospital was overwhelmed with Covid patients. How did staff cope with the onslaught?

item.title: George Floyd death: Why US protests resonate in the UK
item.description: British people explain why the death of George Floyd has had such a big impact in the UK.

item.title: George Floyd: How are African-Americans treated under the law?
item.description: We've looked at some of the data around ethnicity and the US crime and justice system.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown is being lifted across Europe
item.description: As the UK alters its restrictions, how are other European countries reopening after lockdown?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's it like to be laid off over Zoom?
item.description: Being made redundant is rarely pleasant, but is it worse finding out via a video call?

item.title: Coronavirus: Germany divided as states lift lockdown
item.description: Different states are easing lockdown at different rates, and some fear infections could rise again.

item.title: Coronavirus: What might swimming pools be like after lockdown?
item.description: Swimmers might have to arrive in their costumes, with limits on how many people can go in at a time.

item.title: How Europe's art world is welcoming back visitors
item.description: Some of Europe's best known art museums are reopening but it will be far from business as usual.

item.title: Three West Indies players opt out of England tour because of coronavirus fears
item.description: Three West Indies players choose not to travel to England for next month's Test series because of coronavirus fears.

item.title: Amazon to make its Premier League games free when season restarts
item.description: Amazon Prime will make its four Premier League games free-to-air when the season restarts.

item.title: MOTD: Top 10 podcast - rank these iconic home nations moments
item.description: There have been some iconic moments for the home nations since 1966 - but what did BBC Sport pundits consider the best?

item.title: Sancho will not face disciplinary action over 'Justice for George Floyd' T-shirt
item.description: Borussia Dortmund forward Jadon Sancho and other Bundesliga players will face no disciplinary action after tributes to George Floyd.

item.title: Handstand press-ups - Ali Jawad's home workout
item.description: British Paralympic powerlifter, Ali Jawad takes you through four exercises designed to help improve upper body and core strength.

item.title: 'It's a dark place' - Sweden's six-month pre-season
item.description: In Sweden, pre-season - that period hated by so many footballers - is into its sixth month. We find out how players are coping with the physical and mental challenges.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could social distancing of less than two metres work?
item.description: The government is under pressure to relax the 2m social distancing rule - but is it safe to do so?

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Which schools are reopening for pupils?
item.description: Which children are the first to go back to school, and what about the rest?

item.title: NHS test & trace: Does contact tracing stop coronavirus?
item.description: Wales is the latest part of the UK to launch a tracing system, but how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How dangerous is lifting lockdown?
item.description: Why is lifting restrictions being described as a "dangerous moment"?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: You can now meet more people and play certain non-contact sports in the UK - but what are they?

item.title: Coronavirus: Why we don't know how many are being tested
item.description: The UK Statistics Authority has criticised the government's handling of Covid-19 testing data.

item.title: Hay fever v coronavirus: what are the symptoms?
item.description: The Royal College of General Practitioners is warning people not to mix up the symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will shops open and what will the rules be?
item.description: Non-essential shops can reopen in England in June, but will I be able to buy a book or have a haircut?

item.title: Social distancing: A practical guide to how to socialise now
item.description: Meeting friends? Here's how to handle the awkward new rules - from sharing food to avoiding hugs.

item.title: Coronavirus: Parents shamed for back-to-school choices
item.description: Parents of year six and year one pupils have been falling out over whether to send them back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: We answer kids' questions about going back to school
item.description: The BBC's Education Editor Branwen Jeffreys answers kids' questions about going back to school.

item.title: Coronavirus: School return plan 'like a jigsaw puzzle'
item.description: A head teacher explains how she is piecing school life back together before children return.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the risks for children?
item.description: Children seem to be at low risk from the disease, but can they still spread it?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding?
item.description: People most at risk of needing hospital treatment if they get coronavirus are being asked to stay home.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are these targets being hit?
item.description: Ministers have set targets for testing, medical equipment and hospital beds. Have they delivered?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: There is a lot of uncertainty around when and how weddings are allowed to take place. What are your rights?

item.title: Will I still get paid if I have to self-isolate? And other questions
item.description: Will employees still get paid if they are told to self-isolate? And other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: How will social and work life be different after the easing of some restrictions around the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: How safe is it to get on a plane?
item.description: Many airlines are planning to resume flying, but they first need to reduce the risks of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What help are self-employed getting from government?
item.description: What is being done for the five million self-employed people in the UK facing a sudden loss of income?

item.title: Coronavirus: Dental practices to reopen from 8 June
item.description: Dental practices in England have been told they can reopen from Monday, 8 June.

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Fact-checking the row
item.description: Senior Conservatives are still questioning adviser's account of driving his family 260 miles during lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work in England?
item.description: Millions in the UK will soon be asked to monitor who they have been near to combat coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: What can you do in Scotland from Friday?
item.description: After almost 10 weeks of lockdown which restrictions are being eased - and which remain in force?

item.title: Dominic Cummings: Did he break lockdown rules?
item.description: The UK PM's most senior adviser has responded to accusations that he broke lockdown rules - what did he say?

item.title: A cluster of islands: How Shetland locked down early and stopped the virus in its tracks
item.description: Shetland was one of the UK areas worst hit by Covid-19 - now there have been no new cases for six weeks. How did they do it?
